Award.AwardTitle: FTIR Spectroscopy of CO3- and OH-bearing Apatites
Award.AbstractNarration:
Apatite group minerals are made primarily of calcium and phosphate and contain smaller amounts of chlorine, fluorine, hydroxide, carbonate and sulfate. These minor components can be linked through mathematical models to gases (for example, water and carbon dioxide) that are important in many geological processes that lead not only to formation of ore deposits but also to the causes for explosive volcanism. Apatites are found in a wide variety of rocks. Therefore this study will provide the analytical and intellectual basis for an apatite-based mathematical model for carbon dioxide and water behavior in (solid or molten) rocks from the Earth's mantle to surface. One potential application is determining carbon dioxide contributions from volcanoes into the atmosphere at geologic times associated with climate change. A broader impact of this research lies in its presentation as an integral part of the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences' Nature Research Center, an 80,000 square foot facility designed to bring research directly to the general public through a variety of forums and media. Further impact is expected in the understanding of carbonate incorporated into tooth and bone apatite, and in the design of biomaterials.

This research addresses fundamental problems with the apatite group minerals, using microanalytical techniques to enhance the thermodynamic data used in mathematical models. The project will include the development of microanalytical methods for apatites such as Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) for the measurement of OH (hydroxyl ion) and CO3 (carbonate group) in combination with Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (SIMS). Diffusion of fluorine and chlorine in apatite during Electron Probe Microanalysis (EPMA) will be further examined. Apatites will be synthesized in molten salts at temperatures from 600-800°C, providing a simple system for determining (mathematical) thermodynamic data for the pure end member apatites and for the apatites containing mixtures of fluorine, chlorine and hydroxyl ions, and mixtures of hydroxyl ions and carbonate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is formally titled, FTIR Spectroscopy of CO3- and OH-bearing Apatites (Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy = FTIR). Its results go towards the understanding of water- and carbon dioxide-bearing fluids in the earth, in molten rock and metamorphic rock. Earth’s unique geology, tectonics, and evolutionary life forms can be attributed entirely to water and carbon dioxide. Unravelling the contributions of each in the geologic past requires measurement, but the fluids to be measured are often long gone, say, as gasses in a volcanic eruption. Minerals record the conditions under which they form, with water, H2O, incorporated as OH, and carbon dioxide, CO2, incorporated as CO3. Only one common mineral contains both: apatite.

We can add apatite to the mineralogical toolbox, if we have the means to measure OH and CO3 in the crystals (along with chlorine, and fluorine), and if we understand how the composition varies as a function of composition, pressure, and temperature. I attacked this problem on several fronts: synthesis, analysis, and thermodynamics of apatites.

Apatites were synthesized in precise mixtures of molten salts at carefully controlled temperatures and pressures. More than seventy were synthesized in all, but too small for FTIR analysis. Then a donation of temperature control equipment wrecked the furnaces. The equipment was rebuilt four times before NSF funded new furnaces. Experiments continue.

Analytical methods needed to be further refined in electron microprobe analysis, because fluorine and chlorine could not be easily measured by standard methods. This grant subsidized time on a Field Emission electron microprobe, so that a great deal of data could be gathered very quickly. I identified best practices for analyzing synthetic and natural apatite group minerals, and applieds these methods on a suite of apatite crystals from the Fish Canyon Tuff, the largest volcanic eruption known. More than two hundred analyses were collected, and they are still being interpreted.

New tools had to be developed in infrared spectroscopy for OH and CO3, which each have several different signals in the apatites. Molar absorption coefficients (or integrated molar absorption coefficients, AKA extinction coefficients) are required to convert data in the infrared spectra to the concentrations meaningful to scientists. First, these coefficients must be measured in pure synthetic apatites, which were grown at high temperature and pressure in molten salts. My students and I also developed a means of measuring thickness directly from the infrared spectrum, so that tiny crystals did not need to be handled, and possibly lost. A problem arose, in that we were able to produce thousands of spectra, but still had to reduce the data one spectrum at a time. My students loathed the software we used for data reduction, so I had to write my own software to process spectra in batches. The automatic programing allowed us to identify naturally occurring apatites to use as standards. We are now synthesizing and analyzing synthetic mixtures of OH- and CO3-apatite.

Thermodynamics is a mathematical system for describing chemical reactions, in terms of the familiar entropy and enthalpy, but also in less familiar terms of chemical potential and activity.  Thermodynamics allows geoscientists to apply experiments to gain insight into geological processes. Molten salts are thermodynamically simple, so my mineral synthesis experiments can be interpreted very quickly.
